At forty, he was what the inhabitants of the Mystic Quarter called a \"twice-touched soul\" – someone who had experienced both profound love and devastating loss. The morning light filtered through his apartment windows, casting prismatic patterns on the walls – a peculiar effect caused by the city's ambient thaumaturgical field interacting with ordinary glass.Anwesh ran his fingers through his salt-and-pepper hair as he stared at the glowing crystal display of his communication device. Another message from Mitali about their daughter's upcoming Talent Blessing ceremony. Unlike most magical applications that required complex runes and incantations, Smule was designed for simplicity – allowing those with even minimal magical talent to connect through song across vast distances. Next time, try the Raga Bhairav scale instead – it suits your voice better.\"Anwesh laughed. Soumita never held back her critiques, yet somehow they never stung. Perhaps it was the genuine warmth that permeated her every word.\"Voice message or text?\" he asked his system.\"Voice,\" the system responded. \"Personal connection builds stronger magical resonance.\"He cleared his throat. \"Thanks for the save, as always. Maybe you should be teaching vocal enchantments instead of just practicing them. How's the Southern District today? Still suffering those magical storms?\"The relationship between them had evolved gradually from casual musical partners to something deeper. Yesterday, when they'd sung a particularly moving Bengali folk song, listeners reported seeing phantom lotus blossoms floating above their displays.Such manifestations were rare and typically only occurred between those with extraordinarily compatible magical signatures. The implications made Anwesh both excited and nervous.His communication crystal chimed again – Soumita responding almost immediately.\"The storms have calmed, finally. Actually meet, in person?\"The suggestion hung in the air, causing the mandalas on his walls to shift to vibrant purples and golds – reflecting his sudden spike of emotion before he could suppress it.Meeting in person was no small matter. Virtual connections through applications like Smule allowed for controlled magical exchange, but direct contact between compatible practitioners could be unpredictable. What had begun as casual musical collaboration had evolved into something that made her heart race and her magic respond unbidden. Their conversations carried a depth and understanding she'd never experienced before. Anwesh listened – truly listened – to her ideas, her frustrations, her dreams. Remember what happened with Vikram and Sunita last year?\"Soumita winced. You look younger in person.\"\"And you're taller than I imagined.\"They stood there, awkwardly assessing each other while the fountain behind them played increasingly complex harmonies. You've mentioned her in our calls. She's showing musical talent already?\"The fact that she remembered such details about his life – had been listening so carefully all these months – touched him deeply.\"She is. Her Talent Blessing ceremony is next month. It was considered good luck for new relationships to share thoughts under these trees.As they sat on a bench beneath pale blue flowers, Anwesh felt a strange combination of nervousness and absolute comfort. But yes, I'd like that very much.\"At the garden gates, they faced the traditional farewell dilemma of new acquaintances with magical compatibility – physical contact carried unpredictable consequences, yet parting without acknowledgment felt wrong.Anwesh solved the problem by offering his hand, palm up, in the formal gesture of magical respect. \"Until tomorrow, then.\"Soumita placed her palm against his, and the expected spark of golden light appeared – but instead of fading, it expanded into an intricate pattern of interlocking musical notations that hovered in the air between them. Their world—built on voice notes, late-night calls, and shared songs—has created a universe entirely their own, one that transcends the physical boundaries that separate Anwesh's entrepreneurial life from Soumita's youthful ambitions.As we delve deeper into their story, we find ourselves in a world where love finds its way through unlikely channels, where age becomes just a number, and where past heartbreaks serve as stepping stones rather than roadblocks. The magic in their tale isn't found in spells or enchanted forests, but in the everyday miracle of two souls finding each other despite the odds.### The Digital Realm: Where Their Worlds First CollidedThe Smule app—a digital stage where voices meet and blend—became the unexpected foundation of Anwesh and Soumita's shared universe. For Anwesh, a 40-year-old online entrepreneur navigating the aftermath of his divorce from Mitali, his childhood sweetheart, Smule initially represented nothing more than a distraction, a place to reconnect with his passion for music that had been overshadowed by the responsibilities of adulthood and the pain of separation.\"I never thought I'd find anything meaningful there,\" Anwesh often reflects. \"It was just supposed to be a place where I could sing without judgment, where I could express the emotions I kept bottled up during business calls and the brief, awkward conversations with Mitali about our daughter's schedule.\"The digital landscape of Smule created a unique social structure—one where voices could intertwine before faces were ever seen, where connection was built on harmony rather than appearance. This inverted the traditional relationship-building process, allowing Anwesh and Soumita to know each other's souls before they ever knew each other's smiles.For Soumita, ten years younger and unencumbered by the weight of past marriages, Smule was a playground for her musical talents. Her profile, filled with soulful renditions of both Bengali classics and contemporary hits, created a digital persona that was both deeply rooted in tradition yet unafraid to embrace the modern.\"I noticed her voice first,\" Anwesh remembers. \"There was something in the way she sang Rabindra Sangeet—a depth that seemed beyond her years. When I requested to collaborate on 'Ekla Cholo Re,' I wasn't looking for romance. I was looking for someone who understood the song's essence of walking alone despite obstacles. Little did I know that song would become the beginning of our journey of walking together.\"The digital realm they inhabited followed its own rules and customs. Late-night voice messages became their love letters. Scheduled singing sessions became their dates. Comments and reactions from other users became the community that witnessed their growing connection. Within this space, age differences and past relationships held less weight than they might in the physical world of Kolkata's coffee shops and family gatherings.### The Geography of Separation: Kolkata's Physical and Social LandscapesWhile their connection flourished online, the physical world presented a more complex geography. Kolkata, with its blend of colonial architecture and Bengali tradition, was both a shared reference point and a place of separate realities for Anwesh and Soumita.For Anwesh, Kolkata represented a city of memories—streets he had walked with Mitali during their college days, parks where he had pushed his daughter on swings during weekend visits, and the apartment he had once shared with his family, now replaced by a smaller bachelor pad filled with the technology that powered his online business.\"The city feels different when you're divorced,\" Anwesh explains. \"Places you once loved become landmines of memory. I found myself creating new routes, finding new cafés, building a Kolkata that wasn't haunted by what I had lost.\"Soumita's Kolkata was different—a city of possibility rather than memory. Working as a content creator for a local media company, her Kolkata was filled with cultural events, networking opportunities, and the energy of someone still building their career and identity.\"I love this city's contradictions,\" Soumita often says. \"The way ancient traditions and cutting-edge ideas exist side by side. The way you can attend a classical music concert in the morning and a tech startup launch in the evening.\"Their different relationships with the city created a rich tapestry of experiences they could share with each other. Anwesh introduced Soumita to hidden old-world tea shops that had survived decades of modernization, while Soumita brought Anwesh to contemporary art exhibitions that helped him see his hometown through fresh eyes.The social landscape, however, presented greater challenges than the physical one. Kolkata, despite its intellectual progressiveness, still harbored traditional views on relationships, particularly those with significant age gaps or involving divorced individuals.\"My parents are progressive in many ways,\" Soumita confides. \"They supported my career choices, my decision to delay marriage beyond the 'appropriate age' according to our community. But when I mentioned Anwesh—his age, his divorce, his daughter—I saw something in their eyes I hadn't seen before. Fear, perhaps. Or disappointment.\"For Anwesh, the social geography was equally treacherous. His former in-laws, still an active part of his daughter's life, lived in the same neighborhood as his parents. Family friends who had known him and Mitali as a couple now had to navigate the awkwardness of his new relationship.\"Sometimes I feel like I'm asking too much of everyone,\" Anwesh admits. \"Of Soumita, to step into a life with so much complicated history. Of my daughter, to accept someone new in her father's life. Of our families, to embrace a relationship that doesn't fit their expectations.\"### The Timeline of Hearts: Past, Present, and Possible FuturesThe history that shaped Anwesh and Soumita's world began long before they met. For Anwesh, the timeline included meeting Mitali in college, a wedding that their families celebrated as the union of two perfectly matched individuals, the birth of their daughter in 2013, and the slow unraveling of their marriage that culminated in divorce when their daughter was only five.\"When you marry your childhood sweetheart, divorce feels like losing not just your partner but your history,\" Anwesh reflects. \"Mitali knew me when I was still becoming myself. When we separated, I had to figure out who I was without that mirror.\"The years between his divorce and meeting Soumita were marked by Anwesh's transformation from a corporate employee to an online entrepreneur, building a business that allowed him the flexibility to be present for his daughter during his designated time with her while also creating financial stability.Soumita's timeline had followed a different path. The youngest daughter in a family of academics, she had defied expectations by pursuing media rather than medicine or engineering. Her twenties had been filled with short-lived relationships that never quite matched the depth of connection she sought.\"I always felt like I was speaking a language no one around me understood,\" Soumita explains. \"Until I heard Anwesh's voice response to my song. There was something in his interpretation of the lyrics that made me feel recognized in a way I never had before.\"Their shared timeline began in late 2019, with those first musical collaborations gradually evolving into private messages, then phone calls, then video chats that would stretch into the early morning hours. By the time they decided to meet in person in early 2020, they had already built a year of history together, a foundation stronger than many relationships that begin face-to-face.The future timeline, however, remained unwritten and uncertain. Anwesh's responsibilities to his daughter created a fixed point around which other plans had to revolve. Soumita's career aspirations included possibilities of international opportunities. And looming over their individual hopes was the question of whether their families could ever fully accept their relationship.\"I believe in building a future together,\" Anwesh says. \"But I'm also realistic about the complications. My daughter will always be my priority. Soumita deserves someone who can put her first, and I worry sometimes that I can't be that person.\"Soumita, however, sees their potential future differently. \"Who says love has to follow a conventional timeline? We're writing our own story, creating our own traditions. The question isn't whether I'll be first in his life—it's whether we can build a life where everyone feels valued and no one has to be ranked.\"### The Magic System: How Love Transforms Ordinary MomentsIn the fantasy world of Anwesh and Soumita's relationship, the magic system isn't based on spells or supernatural powers, but on the alchemy that transforms ordinary moments into extraordinary memories. Their magic manifests in the way shared music creates a bridge between their separate lives, in how vulnerability becomes strength when expressed to someone who truly listens.The first time they sang together in person, in a small karaoke bar in Kolkata where no one knew them, they discovered that their voices—which had blended so perfectly in digital recordings—required a new kind of attention and adaptation in the physical world.\"It was terrifying,\" Soumita admits. \"Online, you can record and re-record until it's perfect. In person, there's no filter, no chance to edit out the mistakes. I was so nervous I missed my entry point twice.\"Anwesh remembers that moment differently. \"When she faltered, I improvised a little musical bridge to give her time to find her place in the song again. And when she joined back in, her voice was richer, more authentic than in any of our online collaborations. That's when I knew we could create something real together, not just a digitally perfected illusion.\"This magic system has its own rules and limitations. Distance weakens the spell; too many days without seeing each other creates static in their connection. Family obligations can drain the magical energy they generate together. And the shadows of past relationships—particularly Anwesh's marriage to Mitali—can sometimes cast darkness over their brightest moments.Yet they've discovered counter-spells for each of these challenges. Voice notes sent during busy days maintain their connection across distance. Involving each other in family events, even virtually, helps integrate their relationship into their broader lives. And honest conversations about the past, however painful, prevent old ghosts from haunting their present happiness.\"The most powerful magic we've discovered,\" Anwesh says, \"is the ability to see each other clearly—flaws, baggage, and all—and still choose each other every day.\"### The Cultural Tapestry: Bengali Traditions and Modern RelationshipsThe world Anwesh and Soumita navigate is richly textured with Bengali cultural traditions that both enrich and complicate their relationship. Kolkata's cultural calendar—filled with Durga Puja celebrations, literary festivals, and musical performances—provides the backdrop against which their love story unfolds.Their shared love of Rabindra Sangeet connects them to a cultural heritage that values emotional depth and poetic expression. Yet the traditional Bengali society that produced this artistic legacy also maintains certain expectations about marriage, family structure, and appropriate relationships that their union challenges.\"During Durga Puja, when families come together to celebrate, I feel the weight of being without a 'proper' family structure,\" Anwesh confesses. \"My daughter divides her time between me and Mitali, and bringing Soumita into these traditions feels both natural and complicated.\"For Soumita, navigating Bengali cultural expectations as a woman in her thirties who is choosing a divorced man with a child requires a delicate balance between respecting tradition and asserting her right to define her own happiness.\"My mother worries about what our relatives will say,\" Soumita explains. \"In her generation, marrying a divorced man with a child would be seen as settling for less, accepting someone else's problems as your own. I try to help her see that I'm not settling—I'm choosing a partner who has depth and wisdom that comes from experiencing both love and loss.\"Their relationship exists at the intersection of traditional Bengali values and contemporary global perspectives on love and family. They celebrate Poila Boishakh (Bengali New Year) together, but also Valentine's Day. They attend classical music concerts and experimental theater performances. They read both Tagore's poetry and modern relationship psychology books.This cultural hybridity extends to their visions of family life. While respecting the close-knit family structures typical in Bengali households, they're also creating a more flexible model that accommodates Anwesh's co-parenting arrangement with Mitali and Soumita's career ambitions.\"We're not rejecting tradition,\" Anwesh insists. \"We're evolving it. The core Bengali values of emotional intelligence, artistic appreciation, and family loyalty remain central to our relationship. We're just redefining what family can look like.\"### The Supporting Cast: Family Members, Friends, and Former PartnersThe world of Anwesh and Soumita's relationship is populated by a complex cast of characters whose actions and attitudes shape the environment in which their love must survive and thrive.Mitali, Anwesh's ex-wife, remains a significant presence in their story, not as an antagonist but as a co-parent whose well-being is inextricably linked to their daughter's happiness. Their divorce, while painful, was ultimately amicable, with both recognizing that they had grown in different directions.\"Mitali and I share a history and a daughter, but not a future,\" Anwesh explains. \"Learning to transform our relationship from spouses to effective co-parents was one of the hardest challenges I've faced. These aren't arbitrary restrictions but carefully considered boundaries that protect both their connection and their individual needs.The first rule they established concerns Anwesh's daughter. Her emotional well-being takes precedence, which means that plans sometimes change at the last minute if she needs her father. Both have demanding careers that sometimes require full attention, but they've learned that extended silence feeds insecurity and distance.\"We have a three-day rule,\" Soumita shares. \"No matter how busy we get, we don't go more than three days without a meaningful conversation—not just texts or quick calls, but real sharing about what we're experiencing. It keeps us connected even when work pulls us in different directions.\"They've also established boundaries around discussions of Anwesh's past marriage. While honesty about their histories is important, they've learned that constant comparisons or excessive analysis of what went wrong with Mitali only keeps them anchored in the past rather than building their future.\"There's a difference between learning from the past and living in it,\" Anwesh observes. \"I needed to understand why my marriage ended to avoid repeating patterns, but dwelling on it too much prevents me from fully appreciating what's unique and special about my relationship with Soumita.\"Financial independence represents another important boundary. Despite the age gap and income difference, they've maintained separate finances while being transparent about their situations. This preserves Soumita's sense of autonomy and prevents power imbalances from developing.\"I never want Soumita to feel that she's financially dependent on me,\" Anwesh insists. \"That creates an unhealthy dynamic, especially given our age difference. We contribute proportionally to shared experiences, but we each maintain our financial identity.\"Perhaps most importantly, they've established rules around conflict resolution. With complex family dynamics and cultural expectations creating pressure points, they've committed to addressing tensions before they escalate, using \"I feel\" statements rather than accusations, and never involving family members in their disagreements.\"The world around us provides enough challenges,\" Soumita reflects. \"We decided early on that we would be allies in facing those external pressures, not create additional battlefronts between us. His divorce from Mitali five years ago had been amicable on paper but devastating in reality. Childhood sweethearts separated by growing in different directions—the cliché didn't make it hurt any less.\n\n\"You'll see her this weekend, right?\" Soumita asked.\n\n\"Yes, Mitali's dropping her off Friday evening. I've got the whole weekend planned—Science Museum, that new animated film she's been talking about, and I thought we'd try making pasta from scratch.\"\n\n\"She'll love that. You're a good father, Anwesh.\"\n\nHis throat tightened. \"I try. Sometimes I think it would be easier if we lived in the same city.\"\n\nThe silence that followed carried the weight of unspoken complications. His life in Bangalore, Ria and Mitali's in Mumbai, and now Soumita in Kolkata—a triangle of attachments spanning the breadth of India.\n\n\"Have you told her about me yet?\" Soumita asked, her voice careful, measured.\n\n\"Not yet,\" Anwesh admitted. \"I'm waiting for the right moment.\"\n\nAnother silence, heavier than the first.\n\n\"It's been almost a year, Anwesh.\"\n\n\"I know. It's just—Ria was so affected by the divorce. I need to be certain before I introduce someone new into her life.\"\n\n\"And are you? Certain?\"\n\nThe question hung between them, crackling through the digital connection. In the background of Soumita's feed, he could hear the distant sounds of Kolkata traffic, a world away from his quiet Bangalore suburb.\n\n\"I am,\" he said finally. \"About you, I am. It's everything else that's complicated.\"\n\nSoumita sighed, and he could picture her twirling a strand of her curly hair around her finger, a habit she had when processing her thoughts. \"My parents asked about you again today.\"\n\nAnwesh winced. In the traditional Bengali households they both came from, their relationship presented multiple challenges: his divorce, their age difference, the long-distance nature of their connection, and the fact that they had met on a singing app of all places.\n\n\"What did you tell them?\"\n\n\"The truth. That I'm in love with a divorced father of one who lives in another city and whom I've never met in person.\"\n\nAnwesh couldn't help but laugh. \"I'm sure that went over well.\"\n\n\"About as well as you'd expect. Baba went silent, and Ma started listing all the eligible bachelors in our neighborhood.\" Her voice softened. \"But I don't care, Anwesh. I've dated the 'appropriate' men. None of them understood me like you do.\"\n\n\"Even though we've never been in the same room?\"\n\n\"Especially because of that. We connected through music, through words, through ideas. How many couples can say that?\"\n\nOutside, the rain intensified, drumming against the windows like applause. Anwesh closed his eyes, allowing himself to imagine a future where these conversations happened face to face, where Soumita's voice wasn't filtered through technology, where Ria and she could build their own relationship.\n\n\"I've been thinking,\" he said carefully, \"about coming to Kolkata next month.\"\n\nThe sharp intake of breath on the other end told him everything. \"Really? You're not just saying that?\"\n\n\"I've already been looking at flights. I can work remotely for a week, maybe longer.\"\n\n\"Anwesh...\" Her voice wavered. \"Are you sure? This changes everything.\"\n\n\"That's what I'm counting on.\"\n\nAs they talked late into the night, planning his visit with the giddy excitement of teenagers, Anwesh felt something he hadn't experienced in years: hope. Not just for romantic love, but for a new kind of family—unconventional, yes, but perhaps exactly what he needed.\n\n---\n\nThe Howrah Bridge stretched across the Hooghly River like a metal giant, its iconic silhouette visible through the taxi window as Anwesh approached Kolkata. His heart hammered against his ribs, a persistent reminder that after thirteen months of digital connection, he was finally going to meet Soumita in person.\n\nHis phone buzzed with a message: \"I'm already at the café. Nervous but excited. Can't believe this is happening.\"\n\nAnwesh smiled, typing back: \"Traffic on Strand Road. Be there in ten minutes. Don't run away.\"\n\n\"Wouldn't dream of it. I've waited too long.\"\n\nThe taxi crawled through Kolkata's infamous traffic, giving Anwesh time to absorb the city—Soumita's city. The colonial architecture, the street vendors, the cacophony of horns and voices, all so different from Bangalore's tech-oriented landscape. He tried to see it through her eyes, this place she loved despite its challenges.\n\nWhen the taxi finally stopped outside the small café in Park Street, Anwesh paid the driver with trembling hands. Standing on the sidewalk, suitcase beside him, he took a deep breath. Inside that café was the woman whose voice had become his comfort, whose thoughts had intertwined with his, whose laughter had healed parts of him he thought permanently broken.\n\nThe bell above the door chimed as he entered. The café was busy with afternoon patrons, but he spotted her immediately—sitting by the window, wearing a teal kurta, her curly hair cascading past her shoulders. She was more beautiful than her photos, more real than he had dared to imagine.\n\nTheir eyes met across the room. For a moment, neither moved, as if breaking the stillness might shatter the miracle of their finally occupying the same physical space. Then Soumita stood, knocking over her water glass in her haste, and they both laughed, breaking the tension.\n\nThree steps and he was there, standing before her, close enough to notice the tiny mole above her left eyebrow, the flecks of gold in her brown eyes.\n\n\"Hi,\" she said, her voice exactly the same yet entirely different without the digital filter.\n\n\"Hi,\" he replied, suddenly aware of every one of his forty years, of the gray at his temples, of the slight paunch he'd developed despite his best efforts.\n\n\"You're taller than I expected,\" she said, smiling up at him.\n\n\"And you're exactly as beautiful as I knew you would be.\"\n\nShe blushed, the color spreading across her cheeks like watercolor on paper. \"Smooth talker.\"\n\n\"Only with you.\"\n\nThey stood awkwardly for another moment before simultaneously moving in for a hug. The first contact was electric—her warmth, her scent (jasmine and something uniquely her), the solidity of her in his arms. Thirteen months of words, songs, and digital connection crystallized into this embrace, making everything before seem like a pale imitation of reality.\n\nWhen they finally sat down, neither could stop smiling or staring. Their conversation, so fluid online, came in starts and stops as they adjusted to the newness of presence.\n\n\"I can't believe you're actually here,\" Soumita said, reaching across the table to touch his hand, as if confirming his solidity.\n\n\"Neither can I.\" He turned his palm up to hold hers. \"It feels like the most natural thing in the world and the strangest all at once.\"\n\n\"I know exactly what you mean.\" She squeezed his hand. \"I keep thinking I should be more nervous, meeting a man I fell in love with through an app. But it's just you. My Anwesh.\"\n\n\"Your Anwesh,\" he repeated, liking how it sounded. \"And you're my Soumita.\"\n\nThey talked for hours, barely touching their coffee, discovering the small details invisible through screens—how she gestured expressively when excited, how he adjusted his glasses when thinking deeply, the way her nose crinkled when she laughed.\n\nAs evening approached, they walked along the Maidan, the sprawling urban park that was the city's green lung. The October air was pleasantly cool, carrying the scent of street food and distant river.\n\n\"I told my parents I'd bring you home for dinner tomorrow,\" Soumita said, slipping her hand into his. \"They're curious about the man who's stolen their daughter's heart.\"\n\nAnwesh felt a flutter of anxiety. \"Are you sure that's wise? I mean, they know about my situation, right?\"\n\n\"They know everything. And yes, they have their reservations. But they also know I've never been happier.\" She stopped walking to face him. \"They'll love you because I love you. And because you're worth loving.\"\n\nBeneath a banyan tree older than both of them combined, Anwesh kissed Soumita for the first time. The kiss held everything—their past year of connection, their present joy, their uncertain but hopeful future.\n\n\"I spoke with Ria yesterday,\" Anwesh said as they continued walking. \"I told her about you.\"\n\nSoumita looked up, surprise evident. \"You did? How did she take it?\"\n\n\"She had questions. Many questions. Who are you, what do you do, do you like Minecraft, important eleven-year-old concerns.\" He smiled at the memory. \"But she seemed... open to the idea. She said, and I quote, 'Dad deserves to be happy too.'\"\n\nTears welled in Soumita's eyes. \"She sounds wonderful.\"\n\n\"She is. And she wants to video chat with you next week.\"\n\n\"I'd love that.\"\n\nAs night fell over Kolkata, they found themselves on the rooftop restaurant of Soumita's favorite hotel, the city lights spread before them like earthbound stars. Over dinner, they planned the week ahead—places Soumita wanted to show him, work calls he needed to schedule, the dinner with her parents that both excited and terrified him.\n\n\"What happens after this week?\" Soumita asked, voicing the question that had hovered between them for months.\n\nAnwesh took her hand. \"I've been thinking about that. My business is mostly online. I could... relocate, at least part-time.\"\n\n\"To Kolkata?\"\n\n\"It would make sense. I'd be closer to you, and actually closer to Mumbai as well, which means more time with Ria.\"\n\nSoumita's eyes widened. \"You've really thought about this.\"\n\n\"Every day since we started talking. I know it won't be simple. There's Ria to consider, and your career is here, and we'd need to figure out living arrangements that make sense for everyone.\"\n\n\"Not to mention my very traditional Bengali parents who will have opinions about everything,\" Soumita added with a wry smile.\n\n\"Exactly. But I believe we can figure it out, step by step.\" He hesitated. \"Unless you think I'm moving too fast?\"\n\nSoumita laughed, the sound carrying across the rooftop. \"Anwesh, we spent a year getting to know each other's souls before even holding hands. I think we're allowed to accelerate things a bit now.\"\n\nRelief washed over him. \"So you're open to the idea? Of building a life together?\"\n\n\"I'm more than open to it. I'm ready for it.\" Her expression grew serious. \"But I need you to be sure. This isn't just about us. It's about Ria too.\"\n\n\"I know. And that's why I want to do this right.\" He took a deep breath. \"I want you to meet her. In person. Maybe she could come to Kolkata for part of her school holidays, or we could meet in Mumbai.\"\n\n\"I'd like that very much.\"\n\nAs they talked late into the night, planning and dreaming, Anwesh felt the pieces of his fragmented life beginning to align in a new pattern—not perfect, not without challenges, but full of possibility.\n\n---\n\nThe dinner with Soumita's parents went better than expected and worse than hoped. We both recorded the same song and the app matched us for a duet.\"\n\n\"And from there you decided he was husband material?\" Her father raised an eyebrow. \"Without meeting in person?\"\n\nAnwesh cleared his throat. \"Sir, I understand your concerns. In your position, I'd feel the same about Ria—my daughter. But I want to assure you that my intentions toward Soumita are serious and honorable.\"\n\n\"Honorable,\" Mr. Chatterjee repeated. \"Yet you are divorced.\"\n\n\"Baba!\" Soumita protested.\n\n\"It's alright,\" Anwesh said gently. \"Yes, sir, I am divorced. Mitali and I married young and grew in different directions. We tried to make it work for years, especially for Ria's sake, but eventually accepted that we were better parents apart than unhappy together.\"\n\nMrs. Chatterjee, who had been quietly serving more fish curry onto everyone's plates, spoke up. \"And your daughter? Music, the very thing that had connected them, was building a bridge to her family as well.\n\nLater, walking Anwesh back to his hotel (chaperoned at a discreet distance by Soumita's cousin who \"happened\" to be visiting), Soumita apologized for her father's interrogation.\n\n\"Don't apologize,\" Anwesh said. \"He loves you and wants to protect you. Whatever challenges lay ahead—distance, family expectations, blending their lives—they would face them together.\n\n---\n\nThe week in Kolkata passed too quickly.             "content": "# Chapter 1: Melodies Across Distance\n\nIn the sprawling megalopolis of Navaras, where technology and ancient magic had found an uneasy coexistence, lived Anwesh Sengupta. At forty, he was what the inhabitants of the Mystic Quarter called a \"twice-touched soul\" – someone who had experienced both profound love and devastating loss. The morning light filtered through his apartment windows, casting prismatic patterns on the walls – a peculiar effect caused by the city's ambient thaumaturgical field interacting with ordinary glass.\n\nAnwesh ran his fingers through his salt-and-pepper hair as he stared at the glowing crystal display of his communication device. Another message from Mitali about their daughter's upcoming Talent Blessing ceremony. Even after their binding-severance (what outsiders might call a divorce), the magical connection between them remained – thinned but never fully broken, as was the way with childhood sweethearts in Navaras.\n\n\"Damn it,\" he muttered, tapping a quick response. \"Yes, I'll be there. Wouldn't miss Riya's ceremony for anything.\"\n\nAt seven years old, Riya was beginning to show signs of inherent Song Magic – a rare and coveted talent in the Eastern Districts. Not surprising, given both her parents' lineages. The Senguptas had always had strong melodic affinities, though Anwesh had chosen to channel his gifts into the more practical realm of digital enchantments – what the modern world called \"online entrepreneurship.\"\n\nHis apartment reflected this duality – ancient singing bowls and tuning forks alongside crystalline computers and networking arrays. The walls were adorned with traditional Bengali mandalas, each embedded with tiny enchantments that responded to his mood. Today they pulsed with a melancholy blue-green.\n\n\"Time to work,\" he told himself, settling into his enchanted chair that adjusted perfectly to his posture. The chair had been Mitali's parting gift – a gesture of complicated kindness that still confused him three years later.\n\nAs he activated his workstation, the familiar chime of the Smule application echoed through the room. Unlike most magical applications that required complex runes and incantations, Smule was designed for simplicity – allowing those with even minimal magical talent to connect through song across vast distances. It had become wildly popular across all Seven Districts of Navaras.\n\nA notification pulsed: \"SoumiSongbird has responded to your duet request.\"\n\nAnwesh felt a smile tugging at his lips. For nearly a year now, this mysterious woman from the Southern District had been his musical partner. They had never met in person – such was the way of modern magical connections – but their voices had twined together through countless songs, creating minor enchantments that lingered in the digital ether.\n\nHe opened the message, and her voice filled the room – rich, melodious, and carrying the distinct accent of someone raised near the Riverlands.\n\n\"Your harmonies were off on the third verse,\" came her teasing voice. \"But I fixed them. Next time, try the Raga Bhairav scale instead – it suits your voice better.\"\n\nAnwesh laughed. Soumita never held back her critiques, yet somehow they never stung. Perhaps it was the genuine warmth that permeated her every word.\n\n\"Voice message or text?\" he asked his system.\n\n\"Voice,\" the system responded. \"Personal connection builds stronger magical resonance.\"\n\nHe cleared his throat. \"Thanks for the save, as always. Maybe you should be teaching vocal enchantments instead of just practicing them. How's the Southern District today? Still suffering those magical storms?\"\n\nThe relationship between them had evolved gradually from casual musical partners to something deeper. At thirty, Soumita was a decade younger, but in the world of Navaras, where lifespans often reached well past a century, such age differences were considered minimal.\n\nWhat had begun as simple duets had evolved into daily conversations about everything from magical theory to the mundane challenges of daily life. She knew about his failed binding with Mitali, about Riya, about his struggles to balance tradition with innovation in his enchantment business. He knew about her family's expectations that she marry into another musical lineage, her rebellious decision to pursue academic magic instead, and her secret dream of creating a new form of harmonic enchantment.\n\nWhat neither of them had anticipated was how their voices would begin creating spontaneous enchantments – small magical effects that shouldn't have been possible across such distance without formal spellcraft. Yesterday, when they'd sung a particularly moving Bengali folk song, listeners reported seeing phantom lotus blossoms floating above their displays.\n\nSuch manifestations were rare and typically only occurred between those with extraordinarily compatible magical signatures. The implications made Anwesh both excited and nervous.\n\nHis communication crystal chimed again – Soumita responding almost immediately.\n\n\"The storms have calmed, finally. Three days of lightning that sang in perfect fifths! The Elders say it's an omen, but they always say that.\" Her laugh came through clearly. \"Listen, Anwesh... I've been thinking. I have a conference in the Eastern District next month. In Kolkata. Perhaps we could... meet? Actually meet, in person?\"\n\nThe suggestion hung in the air, causing the mandalas on his walls to shift to vibrant purples and golds – reflecting his sudden spike of emotion before he could suppress it.\n\nMeeting in person was no small matter. Virtual connections through applications like Smule allowed for controlled magical exchange, but direct contact between compatible practitioners could be unpredictable. Stories abounded of dramatic magical manifestations, overwhelming emotional transference, even spontaneous binding ceremonies that had to be officially registered after the fact.\n\nYet despite the risks, Anwesh found himself responding without hesitation.\n\n\"I'd like that very much. When exactly will you be here?\"\n\n---\n\nIn the Southern District of Navaras, specifically in the ancient city-within-a-city known as Kolkata, Soumita Chatterjee sat cross-legged on her balcony, surrounded by singing plants that leaned toward her as if listening. At thirty, she embodied what the traditionalists called \"untamed potential\" – a practitioner who had mastered the fundamentals of multiple magical disciplines without committing to a single path.\n\nHer apartment was smaller than Anwesh's but filled with more obvious enchantments – books that read themselves aloud when touched, windows that adjusted their transparency based on her mood, and a collection of musical instruments that played gentle accompaniment to her daily activities.\n\n\"He said yes,\" she told her favorite plant, a rare singing orchid that hummed in response. \"We're actually going to meet.\"\n\nThe prospect filled her with both excitement and trepidation. Her family, the Chatterjees, were among the oldest musical lineages in Navaras, practitioners of classical vocal enchantments for seventeen generations. They had grudgingly accepted her academic pursuits but still expected her to eventually enter a traditional binding with someone from an approved magical family.\n\nHer mother called such matches \"harmonious inevitabilities.\" Soumita called them \"arranged magical mergers\" and had been avoiding the introductions for years.\n\nWhat would her family say if they knew she'd been creating spontaneous enchantments with a divorced entrepreneur from the Eastern District? A man with a child and complicated family history? A man whose magical signature complemented hers in ways that defied traditional matching theories?\n\nShe touched the communication crystal at her throat – a family heirloom that had been enhanced with modern technology.\n\n\"Call Priya,\" she instructed.\n\nHer cousin's face appeared in the air before her, surrounded by the busy backdrop of the University of Mystical Arts where she taught.\n\n\"Let me guess,\" Priya said without preamble, \"you're finally meeting Mystery Man.\"\n\nSoumita smiled. \"Is it that obvious?\"\n\n\"Your aura is practically strobing through the connection. The last time I saw colors like that was when Aunt Lakshmi accidentally drank that emotion-amplifying potion at Diwali.\"\n\n\"It's not like that,\" Soumita protested, though the singing plants around her swayed skeptically. \"We're just musical partners who happen to work well together.\"\n\n\"Musical partners who create manifestation phenomena across districts,\" Priya corrected. \"That's not 'just' anything, Soumi. The department has been tracking your duets, you know. Professor Banerjee nearly fell out of his chair when those lotus blossoms appeared. He's written a paper about it.\"\n\nSoumita groaned. \"Wonderful. Academic scrutiny is exactly what this needs.\"\n\n\"Better than family scrutiny,\" Priya pointed out. \"Speaking of which, have you told Auntie yet?\"\n\n\"About meeting Anwesh? Absolutely not. She'd have a full magical background check run before I could finish the sentence.\"\n\nThe truth was more complicated than Soumita wanted to admit, even to herself. What had begun as casual musical collaboration had evolved into something that made her heart race and her magic respond unbidden. Their conversations carried a depth and understanding she'd never experienced before. Anwesh listened – truly listened – to her ideas, her frustrations, her dreams. He shared his own vulnerabilities in return, something rare among practitioners trained to maintain constant control.\n\n\"Just be careful,\" Priya advised. \"First meetings after strong virtual connections can be... intense. Remember what happened with Vikram and Sunita last year?\"\n\nSoumita winced. The infamous incident had required magical containment specialists and left the Grand Library's east wing closed for renovations for three months.\n\n\"We'll meet in a public place,\" she assured her cousin. \"With dampening charms in place.\"\n\nAfter ending the call, Soumita opened her enchanted journal – a gift from her grandmother that recorded not just her words but traces of her emotional state as she wrote. The pages for the past year were filled with entries about Anwesh, each surrounded by increasingly elaborate magical illuminations that the journal had created spontaneously.\n\n\"One month,\" she whispered to herself. \"Just one month until we actually meet.\"\n\n---\n\nThe weeks leading up to their meeting passed in a flurry of anticipation and preparation. Anwesh found himself uncharacteristically concerned with details he normally ignored – the cut of his clothes, the arrangement of his hair, even practicing certain conversational topics aloud to his empty apartment.\n\nHis daughter noticed the change during their weekly visit.\n\n\"Dad, why are you so jumpy?\" seven-year-old Riya asked, her perceptiveness enhanced by her emerging magical talents. She sat on his living room floor, surrounded by toys that moved and responded to her humming.\n\n\"I'm not jumpy,\" he protested, then immediately knocked over a cup when his communication crystal chimed.\n\nRiya gave him a look of profound skepticism that was eerily reminiscent of her mother. \"Is it because of the singing lady?\"\n\nAnwesh froze. \"What singing lady?\"\n\n\"The one whose songs get mixed with yours. Mom says your magical signature changes when you talk about her.\" Riya shrugged as if this were perfectly ordinary conversation. \"She says it's about time.\"\n\nThe realization that Mitali had noticed – and apparently approved? – left Anwesh momentarily speechless. Their binding-severance had been amicable by legal standards but emotionally complex. They had been childhood friends who had grown into different people with different dreams. The process had been painful but necessary for both of them.\n\n\"Your mother said that?\" he finally managed.\n\nRiya nodded, returning her attention to her toys. \"She says maybe you'll be less grumpy if you have someone to sing with again.\"\n\nThe simple wisdom in his daughter's words struck him deeply. It was true – music had always been his emotional outlet, his connection to the deeper currents of magic that flowed through Navaras. When his binding with Mitali had dissolved, their duets had ended too, leaving a silence that his solo work couldn't fill.\n\nUntil Soumita.\n\nThe realization was both comforting and terrifying. What if their in-person connection didn't match their virtual one? What if the magic between them was merely a technological artifact, not genuine compatibility?\n\nThese fears followed him right up to the appointed day – the spring equinox of 2020, a date of balanced magical energies that seemed fitting for their first meeting.\n\nThey had agreed to meet at the Singing Gardens, a public space in Kolkata where ambient magic was carefully regulated, and emotional outbursts would be gently dampened by the enchanted flora. A practical choice, though Anwesh couldn't help feeling it lacked romance.\n\nHe arrived early, dressed in a traditional kurta that had been subtly enhanced with minor confidence charms (a gift from a grateful client). The gardens were busy with afternoon visitors – families with children, elderly practitioners performing their daily magical exercises, young couples sitting beneath flowering trees that changed colors based on the emotional tenor of conversations beneath them.\n\nAnwesh chose a bench near the central fountain, which played different melodies depending on where one sat to listen. He settled his nerves by focusing on the water's music – a calming raga in a minor key.\n\nHe was so absorbed that he didn't notice her approach until the fountain's melody suddenly shifted, harmonizing with itself in a way he'd never heard before.\n\n\"The fountain only does that for compatible magical signatures,\" came a voice he recognized instantly, though he'd never heard it in person. \"I've studied this garden for years, and I've never seen it respond like that.\"\n\nAnwesh turned, and there she was – Soumita Chatterjee, dressed in a teal silk saree with subtle golden enchantments woven into the border. Her dark hair was swept up with decorative pins that sparkled with tiny containment spells – a sensible precaution for a first meeting. At forty years old, sitting cross-legged on his bed with headphones on, he might have looked ridiculous to an outside observer. But in this moment, as Soumita's voice harmonized with his through the Smule app, he felt more alive than he had in years.\n\n\"That was beautiful,\" Soumita said after they finished their virtual duet of \"Ei Meghla Dine Ekla,\" a Bengali classic that had become their signature song.
