At forty, he had settled into a life that felt both comfortable and hollow—his online business provided financial stability, but the emotional landscape of his existence remained barren since his divorce from Mitali five years prior. Their daughter Riya, now seven, lived primarily with her mother in Kolkata, leaving Anwesh with weekend video calls and holiday visits that never seemed long enough to bridge the growing distance between them.\"Baba, look what I made in school today!\" Riya's voice chirped through the screen, her small hands holding up a watercolor painting of what appeared to be two figures beneath an umbrella.\"That's beautiful, princess,\" Anwesh replied, leaning closer to the screen. \"Is that you and your friend from class?\"Riya's expression fell slightly. \"No, it's you and me walking in the rain. Remember when we did that last time I visited?\"The memory struck Anwesh with unexpected force—their impromptu dance in a sudden Bangalore downpour three months ago, her delighted squeals as he twirled her through puddles. How quickly children grew, how precious those moments became in their absence.\"Of course I remember,\" he said, his voice softening. \"It's the best painting I've ever seen. Will you save it for me until I visit next month?\"After their call ended, the apartment's silence pressed in around him like a physical presence. Anwesh wandered to the balcony, watching lightning illuminate the city skyline in brief, electric flashes. The emptiness of evening stretched before him—no dinner companion, no shared laughter over the day's events, no small body to tuck into bed with stories. Just the hollow echo of a life half-lived.Music had always been his refuge. Even during his marriage to Mitali, when tensions grew and conversations devolved into frigid silences, he would retreat to his harmonium, fingers finding solace in the familiar patterns of ragas that had comforted him since childhood. His grandmother had been his first teacher, guiding his small hands across the keys, teaching him that music was not merely sound but the language of emotions too complex for words.Returning inside, Anwesh picked up his phone and opened the Smule app—a recent discovery that had become an unexpected lifeline. The platform connected musicians across the world, allowing them to collaborate on songs despite physical distance. For someone whose professional life revolved around digital entrepreneurship, this virtual musical community felt like a natural extension of his world.He scrolled through recent collaborations, pausing on a notification: *SoumiS has invited you to join her duet: \"Ekla Cholo Re\"*The Tagore song—\"Walk Alone\"—seemed fitting for his current mood. He tapped on the profile picture, revealing a woman with intelligent eyes and a smile that seemed to hold secrets. Her profile stated simply: *Soumita, 30, Kolkata. Music teacher by day, dreamer by night.*Anwesh hesitated only briefly before accepting the invitation. The original recording featured her clear, confident voice navigating the complex melody with surprising emotional depth. He closed his eyes, listening twice more before recording his part, his baritone complementing her soprano in ways that felt almost conversational—as though they were not strangers separated by technology and geography, but musicians who had performed together for years.When he finished and sent the completed duet, he didn't expect a response until morning. But barely ten minutes later, a message appeared:*Your voice has the quality of old vinyl records—warm and slightly imperfect in all the right ways. Would you like to try another?*Thus began a correspondence that defied the conventional boundaries of time and space. Night after night, their musical dialogue deepened—classical Hindustani compositions giving way to Bollywood classics, Bengali folk songs, and occasionally, English ballads that challenged both their linguistic and vocal ranges.\"You never told me how you started singing,\" Soumita messaged one evening after they had completed a particularly challenging Hemant Kumar composition.Anwesh, sitting cross-legged on his living room floor with a cup of ginger tea, considered her question. \"My grandmother taught me when I was very young,\" he typed. \"She believed music was a form of prayer—not necessarily to any god, but to life itself. What about you?\"\"I was terrible at sports as a child,\" came her reply. \"Completely uncoordinated. My parents tried everything—dance, badminton, even swimming. Then my school music teacher heard me humming during lunch break and told my parents I had 'the gift.' It was the first time I wasn't terrible at something. I've been singing ever since.\"Their exchanges gradually expanded beyond music—tentative at first, then with increasing candor. Anwesh found himself sharing details of his life he rarely discussed: the painful dissolution of his marriage, the guilt he carried over Riya growing up in a broken home, his struggles to remain present in his daughter's life despite the geographical distance.\"Sometimes I wonder if I'm becoming a ghost to her,\" he confessed one night. \"A voice on the phone, a face on a screen. Not a real father.\"Soumita's response came after a thoughtful pause: \"Children understand more than we give them credit for. My father traveled constantly for work when I was growing up. He was physically absent, but emotionally present—he remembered every story I told him, asked follow-up questions weeks later, sent postcards from every city. It wasn't perfect, but I never doubted his love. Quality matters more than quantity.\"Her words carried a wisdom that belied the decade between them. At thirty, Soumita possessed a perspective that seemed shaped by experiences both joyful and painful. She mentioned a previous relationship that had ended badly, leaving her wary of emotional entanglements. She spoke of her music students—children whose parents pushed them toward accomplishments rather than joy, a pattern she gently tried to disrupt.\"I believe we're all born with music inside us,\" she wrote. \"My job isn't to create musicians but to help children find the songs they already carry.\"Six months into their virtual friendship, Anwesh realized something had shifted in his daily rhythms. He found himself checking for Soumita's messages first thing in the morning, sharing observations throughout his day that he thought might amuse her, and staying awake far too late to accommodate their conversations across time zones. When business required him to travel to Chennai or Hyderabad, he found himself calculating the reduced distance to Kolkata, wondering if a detour might be possible.The thought both exhilarated and terrified him. At forty, with a failed marriage and the complexities of co-parenting, he had convinced himself that romantic entanglements belonged to his past. Yet here he was, feeling the unmistakable flutter of anticipation when Soumita's name appeared on his screen, the disappointment when days passed without their musical exchanges.\"I have a conference in Kolkata next month,\" he finally wrote one evening, his heart pounding as though he were a teenager rather than a middle-aged businessman. \"Would you consider meeting for coffee? I understand completely if you'd prefer to keep our friendship virtual.\"The three dots indicating her typing appeared, disappeared, then reappeared several times before her answer came through: \"I'd like that. Music connects souls, but it would be nice to see if our conversational harmony translates to the physical world.\"The weeks leading up to their meeting passed in a blur of anticipation and anxiety. Anwesh found himself scrutinizing his reflection with new critical awareness—the silver threading through his temples, the slight softening around his jawline, the laugh lines etched around his eyes. He was not the young man Mitali had fallen in love with two decades earlier, but a person weathered by experience, carrying both the scars and wisdom of his forty years.The day before his flight to Kolkata, he received a video call from Riya.\"Baba, Maa says you're coming to Kolkata tomorrow!\" Her excitement was palpable, her small face pressed close to the camera. \"Will you visit me? Please?\"The complication he had been avoiding suddenly materialized. His plan had been to fly in for the conference, meet Soumita, and return to Bangalore without disrupting the carefully negotiated custody arrangements with Mitali. Seeing Riya outside their scheduled time together would require explanations he wasn't prepared to provide.\"Princess, this is just a quick business trip,\" he began carefully. \"I have meetings all day and—\"\"But you'll be in the same city!\" Riya's lower lip trembled slightly. \"You never come to see me except for holidays.\"The guilt struck him with physical force. \"Let me talk to your mother, okay? Maybe we can work something out.\"The subsequent conversation with Mitali was tense but civil—the tone they had cultivated over years of co-parenting.\"It's not your scheduled weekend,\" she pointed out, her voice carrying the practiced neutrality they maintained for Riya's benefit.\"I know. It's just dinner, maybe breakfast the next morning before my flight. I miss her, Mitali.\"A pause stretched between them, heavy with unspoken history. \"She misses you too,\" Mitali finally said. \"She can stay with you at your hotel Thursday night if you'd like. I have a late shift at the hospital anyway.\"Relief flooded through him. \"Thank you. I'll pick her up from school?\"\"That would be fine. Anwesh...\" She hesitated. \"Is there another reason you're coming to Kolkata? You usually send Vikram to these conferences.\"The question caught him off-guard. \"Just business,\" he replied, too quickly. \"Nothing important.\"He could almost see her skeptical expression through the phone. After fifteen years of marriage, Mitali could read his evasions like text on a page. \"Alright,\" she said finally. \"Riya will be ready at three. She's been practicing a new song to show you.\"The call ended, leaving Anwesh with a complicated tangle of emotions. His anticipated meeting with Soumita now existed alongside his responsibilities as a father, the boundaries between his past and possible future blurring in ways he hadn't anticipated.He messaged Soumita that evening: \"A change of plans—my daughter will be with me Thursday evening. Would you be willing to meet Friday morning instead?\"Her response was immediate: \"Of course. Family comes first, always. I'd love to hear about your daughter when we meet.\"The simple understanding in her words confirmed what he had already begun to suspect—that their connection transcended the musical collaborations that had initiated it. Though he had grown up in this city, its rhythms now felt simultaneously familiar and foreign, like a song remembered from childhood but with lyrics partially forgotten.The conference passed in a blur of presentations and networking, his mind frequently drifting to the two meetings that anchored his purpose here—Riya and Soumita, the established love and the potential one, his past and possibly his future converging in the city of his birth.When he picked Riya up from school, her delight at the unexpected visit manifested in a running commentary that barely paused for breath—stories about her friends, her classes, a stray cat that visited the school garden, and the upcoming dance recital where she would perform as a butterfly.\"And Maa says I can visit you for two whole weeks this summer!\" she exclaimed as they walked hand-in-hand through the park near his hotel. \"Can we go to that place with the big waterslides again?\"\"Absolutely,\" Anwesh promised, marveling at how quickly she grew—her vocabulary expanding, her thoughts becoming more complex, her personality emerging more distinctly with each visit. \"And maybe we can take a trip to the mountains this time. Would you like that?\"Their evening together was precious in its ordinary moments—helping with homework, ordering room service pizza (a treat Mitali rarely allowed), watching a cartoon movie with Riya nestled against his side, her commentary on the characters interspersed with yawns that grew more frequent as the evening progressed.\"Baba,\" she murmured as he tucked her into bed, her eyes already heavy with approaching sleep. \"Are you lonely in Bangalore?\"The question, delivered with a child's unfiltered directness, caught him unprepared. \"Why do you ask that, princess?\"\"Because sometimes when we talk on the phone, you sound sad. And Maa said that's because you're alone too much.\" She frowned slightly. \"I told her you have your friends and your work, but she said that's not the same as having someone to love.\"Anwesh swallowed hard, wondering what else Mitali had shared with their perceptive daughter. \"I have you to love,\" he said, smoothing her hair back from her forehead. \"That's the most important thing.\"\"But I'm not there,\" Riya pointed out with impeccable logic. \"Maa has Dr. Sanjay now, and they laugh a lot together. You're exactly as I imagined, yet completely different.\"She laughed, taking the seat across from him. \"A contradiction worthy of Tagore himself. Speaking of whom—\" She placed the book of poems on the table between them. \"I brought this not as a recognition signal but because there's a particular verse I wanted to share with you.\"Their conversation flowed with the ease of long acquaintance, moving from music to literature, from childhood memories to philosophical questions, from humorous anecdotes to more vulnerable confessions. At forty, he understood that love was not merely emotion but choice, not just passion but partnership through difficulties. Whatever developed between him and Soumita would require work, patience, and courage from both of them.\"There will be complications,\" he said, giving voice to his concerns. \"The distance, our families, my co-parenting responsibilities, the age difference...\"Soumita's hand found his, her fingers cool against his palm. \"Of course there will be. No dramatic declarations or passionate embraces marked their farewell—only the quiet certainty that they had begun something worth pursuing, a connection that transcended both physical distance and social expectations.Walking back to his hotel, Anwesh felt a sense of alignment he hadn't experienced in years—as though disparate parts of himself were finally finding harmony. At forty, with the accumulated wisdom of both joy and sorrow, he understood that second chances came not as exact replicas of first opportunities but as entirely new pathways, shaped by all that had come before.That night, before sleep claimed him, he sent one final message to Soumita: \"Thank you for reminding me that some of life's most beautiful melodies are those we never expected to hear.\"Her reply arrived moments later: \"The best compositions often arise from improvisation rather than rigid adherence to written notes. I look forward to discovering what music we might create together.\"In the quiet of his hotel room, Anwesh smiled at the perfect metaphor. Their story—begun in virtual harmony and continuing now in the complex reality of physical presence—would indeed be an improvisation, requiring both structure and spontaneity, respect for tradition and courage to create something new.Whatever symphony emerged from their connection would be uniquely theirs—shaped by age and experience, complicated by circumstance, but potentially more beautiful for having been composed not in the simple major key of youth but in the rich, complex harmonies of mature understanding.The melody had only just begun.\n\n---\n\n## Chapter 3: Melodies Beyond Distance\n\n# Chapter 3: Melodies Beyond DistanceThe monsoon rains drummed against the windows of Anwesh's apartment in Kolkata, creating a symphony that reminded him of Soumi's voice—gentle yet powerful, with an undercurrent of emotion that stirred something deep within him. He sat at his desk, the blue light of his computer screen illuminating his face as he scrolled through their messages on Smule. His fingers hovered over the keyboard, hesitating before typing his response to her latest voice note.\"Your rendition of 'Ei Meghla Dine Ekla' was haunting,\" he wrote. \"I could hear the rain in your voice.\"At forty, Anwesh Sengupta had not expected to find himself falling in love again. The dissolution of his marriage to Mitali seven years ago had left him with a daughter he rarely saw and a lingering sense that perhaps love was something that happened once, burned brightly, and then faded into comfortable companionship—or in his case, into nothing at all. Yet here he was, his heart quickening at the sight of a notification from a woman ten years his junior whom he had never met in person.Across the city, in a small apartment adorned with musical instruments and books, Soumita Chatterjee played back Anwesh's latest recording. His voice was rich and textured, carrying the weight of experiences she had yet to live. At thirty, she found herself drawn to the depth in his voice, the way he could convey emotion through the simplest of melodies. She closed her eyes, letting his rendition of Rabindra Sangeet wash over her, imagining the man behind the voice.\"There's something about the way you interpret Tagore,\" she recorded in response. \"As if you've lived every word.\"Their connection had begun innocently enough—two souls who loved music finding each other on an app designed to bring singers together. What had started as casual appreciation for each other's vocal talents had evolved into late-night conversations about literature, philosophy, and the intricacies of Bengali culture that they both cherished despite the different generations they represented.For a year, they had existed in this liminal space—more than friends, less than lovers, connected by technology yet separated by the physical world. The pandemic had both intensified their connection and prolonged their virtual courtship, making the prospect of meeting seem both more necessary and more impossible.\"I think it's time,\" Anwesh typed one evening in late 2020, when restrictions had eased somewhat. \"I want to hear your voice without digital interference. I want to see if your eyes crinkle when you laugh the way I imagine they do.\"Soumi's response came after what felt like an eternity: \"Victoria Memorial, this Sunday, 4 PM. I'll be wearing a teal saree with a silver border.\"The days leading up to their meeting passed in a blur of anticipation and anxiety for Anwesh. He found himself standing before his wardrobe, discarding outfit after outfit, feeling like a teenager preparing for his first date rather than a divorced entrepreneur with greying temples. He settled on a simple cotton kurta, not wanting to appear as though he was trying too hard, yet still wanting to honor the significance of the occasion.On Sunday, the gardens surrounding Victoria Memorial were alive with families and couples enjoying the winter sunshine. Anwesh arrived thirty minutes early, his hands damp with nervousness as he paced the paths, rehearsing what he would say when he finally saw her.And then, there she was—a vision in teal, her saree catching the golden light of the setting sun. Soumi stood by the reflecting pool, her gaze searching the crowd. When their eyes met, there was a moment of recognition so profound that Anwesh felt it physically, like a chord struck perfectly in tune.\"Anwesh?\" she said, her voice exactly as it sounded in her recordings, yet somehow more real, more present.\"Soumi,\" he replied, and in that single word was a year of waiting, of wondering, of hoping.They walked together through the gardens, their conversation flowing as easily in person as it had online. Anwesh found himself studying her—the way she gestured with her hands when she spoke passionately about music, the small dimple that appeared when she smiled, the intelligence that sparkled in her eyes when she debated a point.\"You know,\" Soumi said as they sat on a bench overlooking the memorial, \"my mother thinks I'm mad to be meeting a man from the internet, especially one who's...\"\"Old enough to be your father?\" Anwesh supplied with a self-deprecating smile.\"I was going to say 'experienced,'\" she corrected, her eyes twinkling with mischief. \"But yes, the age difference has been a point of contention.\"Anwesh nodded, understanding all too well the obstacles that lay before them. \"My daughter Ria is twelve now,\" he said. \"Almost a teenager. I'm not sure how she would feel about her father dating someone closer to her babysitter's age than his own.\"The mention of his daughter brought a shadow to his face. Soumi noticed, reaching out to touch his hand lightly. \"Tell me about her,\" she encouraged.And so he did, speaking of Ria's intelligence, her passion for dance, her quiet resilience in the face of her parents' divorce. He spoke of the guilt that haunted him—the missed birthdays, the school performances he had attended as an audience member rather than a participant in her daily life.\"Mitali has primary custody,\" he explained. \"It was the right decision. My work schedule is unpredictable, and she provides stability. But sometimes I wonder if I've failed as a father by not fighting harder to be present.\"\"Or perhaps you've succeeded by recognizing what was best for her, even at your own expense,\" Soumi suggested gently.As the evening deepened around them, they found themselves reluctant to part. They moved from the gardens to a small café, where they ordered coffee and continued their conversation, now touching on their families, their dreams, the complications that awaited them if they pursued what was growing between them.\"My parents are traditional,\" Soumi explained. \"They expect me to marry a man of their choosing—someone my age, from a similar background, with a stable profession. A divorced entrepreneur who creates online courses would not be their first choice.\"\"And what would be your choice?\" Anwesh asked, his voice low, his eyes fixed on hers.Soumi held his gaze. \"I've always believed that the heart knows what it wants, even when the mind counsels caution.\"That first meeting extended into dinner, and dinner into a walk along the Hooghly River, the lights of Howrah Bridge reflecting in the dark waters. When they finally parted, it was with the promise to meet again the following weekend.One meeting became two, then three, then a regular part of their lives. They discovered shared tastes in music beyond what they had revealed online—a mutual appreciation for the fusion of Eastern and Western traditions, for the experimental works of contemporary Bengali composers. They debated literature, Anwesh defending the classics while Soumi championed modern authors who challenged conventions.Their relationship deepened, but not without complications. Anwesh's ex-wife, Mitali, expressed concern when she learned he was dating someone so much younger.\"What will Ria think?\" she demanded during one of their co-parenting conversations. \"She's already struggling with having divorced parents. Now her father is having a midlife crisis with a woman barely out of college?\"\"Soumi is thirty, with a master's degree in classical music and a teaching position at the university,\" Anwesh replied, keeping his voice level despite the anger bubbling beneath the surface. \"And what Ria needs to see is that her father can find happiness again, that life continues after disappointment.\"Mitali's skepticism was mirrored by Soumi's family. Her parents, upon learning of her relationship with an older, divorced man, had reacted with predictable dismay.\"We did not educate you so that you could throw your life away on someone else's leftovers,\" her father had said harshly. \"He has lived his life, made his choices. Why should you bear the consequences?\"Soumi had stood her ground, her voice shaking but determined. \"Anwesh is not 'leftovers,' Baba. He is a man who has experienced loss and learned from it. He values what we have because he knows what it means to lose something precious.\"Despite these external pressures, their relationship continued to flourish. Anwesh found in Soumi a partner who challenged him intellectually and emotionally, who brought music back into his life in a way that had been absent since his youth. Soumi discovered in Anwesh a depth of understanding that she had not found in men her own age, a patience and wisdom that complemented her youthful enthusiasm.Six months into their relationship, Anwesh made the decision to introduce Soumi to his daughter. He arranged for them to meet at a casual setting—a bookstore café that Ria loved, where the pressure would be minimal.\"She's not trying to be your mother,\" Anwesh explained to Ria beforehand. \"She's someone who is important to me, and I hope you can give her a chance.\"Ria, with the direct honesty of a twelve-year-old, had looked at him skeptically. \"Is she why you and Mom won't get back together?\"The question had caught Anwesh off guard. \"No, sweetheart. Your mother and I decided to end our marriage long before I met Soumi. Sometimes people grow in different directions, even when they still care about each other. But that doesn't change how much we both love you.\"The meeting itself had been awkward at first, with Ria responding to Soumi's friendly overtures with monosyllabic answers. But when Soumi mentioned that she taught music and could play six different instruments, Ria's interest was piqued.\"Could you teach me to play the guitar?\" she asked, her first voluntary contribution to the conversation.\"I'd be honored,\" Soumi replied, her smile genuine. \"Your father tells me you have a natural ear for music.\"By the end of the afternoon, Ria was showing Soumi videos of her dance performances, and Soumi was promising to help her create original music for her next recital. It wasn't instant acceptance, but it was a beginning.As summer turned to autumn, Anwesh and Soumi's relationship faced its most significant test. Soumi was offered a prestigious fellowship at a conservatory in Vienna—a one-year opportunity that could launch her career internationally.\"You have to take it,\" Anwesh insisted when she showed him the offer letter, his heart sinking even as he forced enthusiasm into his voice. \"This is what you've been working toward.\"Soumi looked at him, her eyes searching his face. \"But what about us? A year is a long time to be apart, especially when we're still building something.\"\"We built our connection online for a year before we ever met in person,\" Anwesh reminded her. \"We can survive this. I'm not going anywhere.\"The night before Soumi's departure was bittersweet. They sat on the rooftop of her apartment building, looking out over the city lights, speaking of the future in carefully hopeful terms.\"I've been thinking,\" Anwesh said, his voice quiet in the darkness. \"When you return, perhaps we could consider living together. My apartment is closer to the university, and it has that spare room that would make a perfect studio for your music.\"Soumi turned to him, surprise evident in her expression. \"Are you sure? That's a big step, especially with Ria to consider.\"\"Ria likes you,\" Anwesh said. \"And I... I love you, Soumi. I didn't expect to find this again, especially not with someone who came into my life through a singing app. But here we are.\"Soumi's eyes glistened with tears as she leaned forward to kiss him. \"I love you too,\" she whispered against his lips. \"And yes, when I return, I would like to build a home with you.\"The year of separation was challenging but ultimately strengthening for their relationship. They scheduled regular video calls, shared their daily experiences through messages and voice notes, and continued their musical collaboration remotely. Anwesh visited Vienna twice, marveling at Soumi's growth as an artist in this new environment. Soumi returned to Kolkata for Durga Puja, spending time not only with Anwesh but also with Ria, whose initial wariness had evolved into genuine affection.When Soumi finally returned to Kolkata permanently, it was to a changed landscape. Mitali, seeing the seriousness of Anwesh's relationship with Soumi and the positive influence she had on Ria, had softened her stance, even inviting Soumi to Ria's school concert.Soumi's parents, impressed by Anwesh's unwavering support of their daughter's career and the respect he showed for their traditions, had begun to accept the relationship, though her father still occasionally made pointed comments about the age difference.Moving in together brought its own challenges—the negotiation of space, the blending of possessions, the daily intimacies that can either strengthen or strain a relationship. Anwesh, accustomed to living alone and setting his own schedule, had to adjust to sharing his space and his time. Soumi, who had lived with roommates but never with a partner, had to learn the rhythms of Anwesh's life, including the days when Ria stayed with them.Yet amid these adjustments, they found a harmony that echoed their musical collaboration. They established routines that honored both their individual needs and their shared life. Sunday mornings were reserved for music—Anwesh on the harmonium, Soumi with her sitar, their voices blending in the songs that had first brought them together. Weekday evenings often found them working side by side, Anwesh developing his online courses while Soumi composed or graded student assignments.And on the weekends when Ria stayed with them, they created new traditions—Saturday afternoon cooking sessions where they prepared dishes from different regions of India, evening walks along the river, Sunday morning music lessons where Ria's improving guitar skills were showcased.It was during one such weekend, almost two years after they had first met in person, that Anwesh proposed. They were at Victoria Memorial again, sitting on the same bench where they had talked during their first meeting. Ria was with them, in on the secret, carrying the small velvet box in her pocket until the perfect moment.\"Do you remember what you said to me here?\" Anwesh asked Soumi, taking her hand in his. \"You said the heart knows what it wants, even when the mind counsels caution.\"Soumi nodded, a smile playing at the corners of her lips. \"I remember.\"\"My heart knew from the first note I heard you sing,\" Anwesh continued. \"It took my mind longer to catch up, to believe that this could be real, that I could be fortunate enough to find love twice in one lifetime. But now both my heart and mind are in agreement.\"He nodded to Ria, who produced the box with a flourish and handed it to him. Anwesh opened it to reveal a ring with a single sapphire surrounded by smaller diamonds.\"Soumita Chatterjee, will you marry me? Will you continue to create music with me, to build a life with me, to blend your story with mine and Ria's?\"Tears spilled onto Soumi's cheeks as she nodded, too overcome to speak. Ria, watching with wide eyes, broke the emotional silence.\"Does this mean I get to call you 'Soumi Ma' now?\" she asked, using the Bengali term for mother.Soumi laughed through her tears, opening her arms to include Ria in an embrace that encompassed all three of them. \"If you want to,\" she said. \"But you can also just call me Soumi. What matters is that we're family now.\"The wedding planning brought its own set of challenges. Soumi's parents, while accepting of the relationship, insisted on a traditional Bengali ceremony. Anwesh, conscious of the fact that this was his second marriage, preferred something simpler. Mitali had concerns about how Ria would be included in the ceremony and what role she would play in this newly formed family.Through patient negotiation and compromise, they arrived at a solution that honored tradition while acknowledging their unique circumstances. The ceremony would be traditional but intimate, held in the garden of a heritage hotel rather than a temple. Ria would have a special role, carrying the garlands that the bride and groom would exchange. And Mitali would be invited not as Anwesh's ex-wife but as Ria's mother and an important figure in their daughter's life.On the day of the wedding, as Anwesh waited for Soumi to complete her bridal preparations, he found himself reflecting on the journey that had brought them to this point. From a chance connection on a singing app to a love that had weathered family disapproval, separation, and the complexities of blending lives, they had created something beautiful and unexpected.When Soumi finally appeared, resplendent in a red Benarasi saree, her face partially hidden behind the traditional veil, Anwesh felt the same surge of emotion he had experienced when he first heard her sing. There was a rightness to this moment, a sense that despite all odds, they had found their way to where they were meant to be.The ceremony proceeded with the timeless rhythm of Bengali tradition—the exchange of garlands, the circumambulation of the sacred fire, the binding of hands with the sacred thread. Ria performed her role with solemn dignity, though she couldn't resist giving Soumi a quick hug before returning to her seat beside her mother.During the feast that followed, Anwesh noticed Mitali and Soumi deep in conversation, their heads bent together, occasional laughter rising between them. I was just looking for someone who understood music the way I did.\"\"And I was just trying to reconnect with a part of myself I thought I had lost,\" Anwesh admitted. \"I never expected to find a whole new life.\"They stood in comfortable silence, listening to the fading sounds of the celebration, the distant notes of the shehnai still playing softly.
